questions.text: Drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever is? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin

 

Aspirin is the drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever due to its efficacy in reducing inflammation and managing symptoms like arthritis and carditis, which are common in rheumatic fever. The other listed drugs are not used for this condition and are more specific to heart diseases and arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: This medication is a cardiac glycoside, typically used in heart failure and certain arrhythmias. It is not used in the treatment of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication used primarily for the treatment of various cardiac arrhythmias. It is not indicated for acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic, often used in conditions like heart failure and hypertension. It is not a treatment for acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory drug and is commonly used in the treatment of acute rheumatic fever, particularly for its anti-inflammatory effects in managing arthritis and carditis associated with rheumatic fever.

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem of the lateral sulcus

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image points to the region where the parietal lobe and temporal lobe meet. This region is associated with the lateral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to this marked structure, separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central sulcus: Incorrect. The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and is not located in the region marked in the image.

 

Option C. Inferior frontal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus is found on the lateral surface of the frontal lobe and does not correspond to the marked region.

 

Option D. Superior temporal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus runs parallel to the lateral sulcus on the temporal lobe, but it is not deep to the marked structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to the marked structure in the image, which is a critical landmark in neuroanatomy for separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by the D cells of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Somatostatin

 

Explanation: 

 

The pancreatic islets contain at least four distinct cell types: A, B, D, and F cells. Each of these cell types secretes a specific hormone. The D cells (also called δ cells) specifically secrete somatostatin. The cells in the islets are divided into types based on their staining properties and morphology. The A cells secrete glucagon, the B cells secrete insulin, the D cells secrete somatostatin, and the F cells secrete pancreatic polypeptide.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Gastrin - Gastrin is not secreted by pancreatic islet cells. It's a gastrointestinal hormone that can affect glucagon secretion, but it's not produced by D cells.
  • Option B. Insulin - Insulin is secreted by B cells (β cells), not D cells.
  • Option C. Glucagon - Glucagon is specifically secreted by A cells (α cells). 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The pancreatic islets contain four specialized cell types (A, B, D, and F), each secreting a different hormone (glucagon, insulin, somatostatin, and pancreatic polypeptide respectively), with somatostatin being specifically secreted by the D cells.

questions.text: A 47-year-old renal transplant patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oval cysts 30 x 15 microns as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the causative organism:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isospora

 

In this case, the patient is a renal transplant recipient, indicating an immunocompromised state due to immunosuppressive drugs. Immunocompromised patients are more susceptible to infections, including parasitic infections causing diarrhea.

 

The stool examination revealed oval cysts measuring 30 x 15 microns, which were acid-fast positive. These characteristics are crucial in identifying the parasite:

 

  1. Immunocompromised State: This condition makes the patient more prone to infections by opportunistic parasites.
  2. Acid-Fast Positive Cysts: This staining characteristic is seen in certain parasitic cysts.
  3. Size and Shape of Cysts: The cysts are oval and measure 30 x 15 microns.

 

Based on the provided images and reference notes, Isospora belli (now known as Cystoisospora belli) is the parasite that fits these criteria. Isospora cysts are known to be oval in shape and measure approximately 20 to 30 microns in length, consistent with the 30 x 15 microns cysts described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium cysts are round, not oval, and are much smaller (4 to 6 microns). They do not fit the size and shape described in this case.

 

Option C. Cyclospora: Cyclospora cysts are also round and measure approximately 8 to 10 microns, which do not match the size and shape given in the question.

 

Option D. Microsporidia: Microsporidia produce very small spores (1 to 2 microns) and are not typically described as having 30 x 15 microns cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isospora belli (Cystoisospora belli) causes watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients and is identified by its oval cysts measuring approximately 20 to 30 microns, which are acid-fast positive.

choices.text: BP should be checked multiple times before administering anti-hypertensives
In haemorrhagic stroke, you should aggressively treat with intravenous anti-hypertensives
In haemorrhagic stroke, BP should be reduced to 160/100 mmHg with anti-hypertensives
BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium and his BP was 220/110 mmHg. He also had one episode of vomiting and on examination has weakness in the left upper and lower limbs. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

 

In acute ischemic stroke, blood pressure is often elevated as a physiological response to maintain perfusion to the ischemic penumbra. Unless:

 

  • The patient is receiving thrombolysis, in which case BP should be <185/110 mmHg, or
  • The BP is severely elevated (>220/120 mmHg),

 

You should not acutely lower the blood pressure. Lowering it to <140/90 mmHg immediately is contraindicated, as it can worsen cerebral hypoperfusion and enlarge the infarct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP should be checked multiple times before administering anti-hypertensives: Correct. Rechecking BP ensures accuracy and avoids overtreatment of transient spikes. Stroke protocols depend on consistently high values.

 

Option B. In haemorrhagic stroke, you should aggressively treat with intravenous anti-hypertensives: Correct. Rapid BP control reduces ongoing bleeding and hematoma expansion. Agents like labetalol and nicardipine are preferred.

 

Option C. In haemorrhagic stroke, BP should be reduced to 160/100 mmHg with anti-hypertensives: Correct. Target BP of <160/100 mmHg is generally accepted to balance the risk of further bleeding with maintaining cerebral perfusion. Even though it is not a specific recommendation in haemorrhagic stroke, it is acceptable.

 

Trials that are important –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific blood pressure targets in acute stroke:

 

  • General recommendation in hypertensive emergency: Reduce BP by 25% in 1st hour, then target around 160/100 mmHg within 2–6 hours
  • Ischemic stroke with thrombolysis: <185/110 mmHg
  • Ischemic stroke without thrombolysis: <220/120 mmHg
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke: Controversial – SBP <140 mmHg (INTERACT2) vs. 140–180 mmHg (WHO 2021)

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of migration of neural crest cells

 

Hirschsprung disease is caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall.

 

Hirschsprung disease, also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon, occurs when the normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum is interrupted or the ganglion cells die prematurely. This results in a distal intestinal segment with neither the Meissner submucosal nor the Auerbach myenteric plexus ("aganglionosis"). Coordinated peristaltic contractions are absent, and functional obstruction occurs, resulting in proximal dilation.

 

The absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel leads to an inability to coordinate peristaltic contractions, resulting in functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation. This can lead to symptoms such as abdominal distension, constipation, and failure to pass meconium shortly after birth.

 

The diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is made based on a combination of clinical presentation, radiographic findings, and histologic examination of rectal biopsy specimens. Treatment typically involves surgical resection of the aganglionic segment of the bowel, followed by re-anastomosis or creation of a colostomy.

 

Complications of Hirschsprung disease include enterocolitis, fecal impaction, and even sepsis, so early diagnosis and prompt treatment are important to prevent these complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of ganglion cells: While the result of the disease is a bowel segment lacking ganglion cells, the primary cause is the failure of migration of neural crest cells rather than a secondary loss of ganglion cells.

 

Option C. Visceral myopathy: Visceral myopathy involves primary muscle pathology of the bowel, which is not the cause of Hirschsprung disease.

 

Option D. Obstruction by inflammatory stricture: Inflammatory strictures are not related to the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease, which is due to congenital aganglionosis rather than inflammation or stricture formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung disease is primarily caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall during embryonic development, resulting in aganglionosis in the distal bowel and leading to functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation.

questions.text: A bank employee, felt depressed with no interest in activities, came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea, or excessive saliva production, is not a common side effect of SSRIs like escitalopram. It is more commonly associated with the atypical antipsychotic drug clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia, or difficulty achieving orgasm, is a well-known side effect of SSRIs due to their impact on serotonin levels, which can interfere with sexual function.

 

Option C. Nausea: Nausea is one of the most common side effects of SSRIs. It typically occurs at the beginning of treatment and may subside with continued use.

 

Option D. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams are another common side effect of SSRIs. They occur due to the influence of increased serotonin levels on sleep patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Escitalopram is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).
  • Other SSRIs include Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Fluvoxamine etc.
  • Side-effects of SSRI include:
  • Most common: Nausea, Vomiting
  • Next most common: Anxiety etc.
  • Other side effects- Delayed ejaculation, anorgasmia, diarrhea, vivid dreams etc.
  • Main drug which causes sialorrhea is CLOZAPINE (an atypical anti-psychotic drug)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/488

choices.text: The abdominal part of the esophagus is supplied by the left gastric artery
It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium
The cervical part of the esophagus is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the esophagus is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium

 

Explanation:

 

The esophagus is lined by stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium, not ciliated columnar epithelium. This epithelium forms a protective layer resistant to abrasion from food passing through the esophagus. The lamina propria consists of loose connective tissue with papillae, and the muscularis mucosae becomes more distinct in the lower part formed by longitudinal muscle fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is approximately 25 cm long - This is correct. The esophagus is approximately 25 cm long, and is one of several structures in the body that measure about 25 cm, including the duodenum, ureter, descending colon, and stomach.

 

Option B. The abdominal part of the esophagus is supplied by the left gastric artery - This is correct. The lower 1/3rd part of the esophagus, including the abdominal portion, receives its arterial supply from the esophageal branches of the left gastric artery.

 

Option D. The cervical part of the esophagus is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery - This is correct. The upper 1/3rd part of the esophagus (cervical part) is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The esophagus is lined by stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium, which provides protection against abrasion, whereas ciliated columnar epithelium is found in respiratory passages and certain parts of the female reproductive tract.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is commonly used to visualize and detect blood stains, even after they have been washed out? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Luminol test

 

Explanation:

 

The luminol spray test is specifically designed for detecting invisible blood stains including those on cleaned surfaces where blood has been washed out. Luminol (aminophthalhydrazide) produces a blue-white to yellowish-green chemiluminescent glow when it reacts with the peroxidase activity in blood, even in minute quantities. This test is particularly useful for locating and defining areas of blood on cleaned floors and old blood stains, and is considered the most sensitive among presumptive blood tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infrared photography - Used for enhancing visualization of ink differences in documents, gunshot residues, or bruises under skin—not suitable for detecting washed-away blood stains.

 

Option C. Ultraviolet light - UV light is useful for detecting fluorescent substances, especially seminal stains, saliva, or urine. Blood does not fluoresce under UV and may actually absorb UV light, appearing as dark areas. Washed-out blood will not be detectable under UV.

 

Option D. Magnifying lens - Merely magnifies visible stains, offers no utility in detecting stains that are washed out or invisible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The luminol spray test is the most sensitive presumptive tool for detecting latent or washed-out blood stains. It produces a blue-white glow in darkness due to a chemiluminescent reaction with the heme group in blood. Though highly sensitive, it is not confirmatory and may react with non-blood oxidizing substances, necessitating confirmatory tests afterward.

choices.text: Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath
Flexed resting posture of the finger
Pain on passive flexion of the finger

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Kanavel Signs of pyogenic flexor tenosynovitis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Pain on passive flexion of the finger

 

Kanavel's signs are the classic diagnostic features of pyogenic flexor tenosynovitis. The four cardinal signs include tenderness along the tendon sheath (the most specific sign), flexion of the finger at rest, fusiform (uniform) swelling of the finger, and pain on passive extension of the finger (not flexion). Pain occurs during extension because stretching the infected tendon sheath exacerbates the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath: This is a correct Kanavel sign and is considered the most specific feature of flexor tenosynovitis. The tenderness follows the course of the infected tendon sheath.

 

Option B. Flexed resting posture of the finger: This is a correct Kanavel sign. The infected finger is typically held in slight flexion as this position minimizes tension on the inflamed tendon sheath.

 

Option C. Fusiform swelling of the finger: This is a correct Kanavel sign. The swelling in tenosynovitis is uniform throughout the length of the finger due to the inflammation of the entire tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kanavel's signs for diagnosing flexor tenosynovitis include tenderness along the tendon sheath, flexed position of the finger, uniform (fusiform) swelling, and pain on passive extension (not flexion) of the finger.

questions.text: A 60-year-old vegetarian patient presented with weakness and reduced work capacity. He had a Hb of 10gm/dl and MCV-110. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

 

  • Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by the presence of large, abnormal red blood cells (megaloblasts) in the bone marrow. It is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folic acid, both crucial for DNA synthesis in the production of red blood cells. The high mean corpuscular volume (MCV-110) indicates that the red blood cells are larger than normal, which is typical in megaloblastic anemia. Being vegetarian, the patient is at a higher risk of vitamin B12 deficiency, commonly seen in diets lacking in animal products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: Typically presents with a low MCV (microcytic anemia), not high, as it indicates smaller than normal red blood cells.

 

Option B. Aplastic anemia: Involves pancytopenia (reduction of all blood cell types) and does not typically present with high MCV.

 

Option D. Thalassemia: Generally presents with a low MCV and affects the production of hemoglobin. It is a genetic disorder rather than related to dietary habits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of anemia with high MCV, especially in vegetarians or those with dietary restrictions, megaloblastic anemia should be considered. Vitamin B12 and folate levels should be assessed to confirm the diagnosis, and dietary intake of these vitamins should be evaluated and corrected if deficient.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has appreciable shortening in her right leg. She is diagnosed with TB Hip. Her presentation will come under which stage? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage III

 

STAGES OF TUBERCULOSIS OF HIP

 

  • Stage 1: 
    • Stage of synovitis
    • FABER (Flexion, Abduction and External rotation)
    • Lengthening
  • Stage 2: 
    • Stage of early arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • <1 cm shortening
  • Stage 3: 
    • Stage of advanced arthritis
    • FADIR (Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation) 
    • >1 cm shortening
    • Appreciable shortening is a key characteristic.
  • Stage 4: 
    • Stage of subluxation/dislocation
    • Wandering acetabulum or pestle and mortar appearance
  • Stage 5: 
    • Stage of sequelae, ankylosis or severe arthritis

 

 

Wandering acetabulum (actually wandering femur head)

 

 

Additionally,

  • Stage V: Described as a "fused, finished off joint" known as fibrous ankylosis. This stage represents the end progression of certain joint diseases where there is complete fusion of the joint surfaces.
  • In TB affecting peripheral joints, such as the hip and knee, the fusion is more commonly fibrous ankylosis, where the fusion involves more fibrous tissue rather than direct bone fusion. This is painful condition. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I:

  • Known as the stage of synovitis.
  • Characterized by increased capacity of the hip.
  • The position of comfort is FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation).
  • FABER leads to lengthening of the leg, not shortening.

 

Option B. Stage II:

  • Early arthritis stage with joint damage.
  • The lower limb adopts a position of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.
  • Shortening is present but is > 1 cm and not appreciable.

 

Option D. Stage IV:

  • Involves destruction of the bone and changes in the shape of the joint.
  • The femoral head migrates, causing subluxation or dislocation.
  • Known as the stage of the wandering acetabulum, a misnomer for the wandering femoral head.
  • Not specifically associated with the appreciable shortening described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Stage III of TB hip is characterized by late or advanced arthritis with appreciable shortening of the leg (> 1 cm).

questions.text: All of the following drugs cause miosis, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Phenothiazines

 

Explanation:

 

Miosis refers to pupillary constriction, often described as "pinpoint pupils" in severe cases. Phenothiazines, which include chlorpromazine and other antipsychotic medications, produce mydriasis (pupillary dilation) rather than miosis due to their antagonistic effects on muscarinic cholinergic receptors. This anticholinergic activity blocks the parasympathetic stimulation of the pupillary sphincter muscles, preventing constriction and allowing for pupillary dilation.

 

In toxicological assessment, pupillary examination is critical because it often provides immediate diagnostic clues. The classic triad of opioid toxidrome includes respiratory depression, CNS depression, and miosis. This characteristic pinpoint pupil appearance has high diagnostic value, particularly when unresponsive to light in severe intoxication. Pupillary changes usually persist even in comatose states, making them valuable signs when patients cannot provide history.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Clonidine - Produces miosis through its alpha-2 adrenergic agonist effects. This centrally-acting antihypertensive consistently causes pupillary constriction that can be distinguished from opioid-induced miosis by its responsiveness to light.
  • Option B. Morphine - Causes significant miosis by stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system. The miosis is often extreme and unreactive to light stimuli in significant overdose, making it a cardinal sign in opioid toxicity.
  • Option C. Meperidine - As with other opioids, it produces pupillary constriction through mu-receptor activation. This effect is dose-dependent and remains present even when other symptoms fluctuate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pupillary examination provides rapid diagnostic information in toxicology cases - miosis indicates opioids, organophosphates or clonidine, while mydriasis suggests anticholinergics, sympathomimetics, or phenothiazines like chlorpromazine.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

 

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

 

Nerve supply of external auditory canal

 

External Auditory Canal

 

  1. Anterior wall and roof: auriculotemporal (V3).
  2. Posterior wall and floor: auricular branch of vagus (CN X) aka Arnolds nerve
  3. Posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibres of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus

 

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): Stimulation of Arnold's nerve in the external auditory canal during wax removal evokes reflex cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve - Provides sensation to the anterior wall and roof of the canal, not typically associated with triggering cough.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve - Primarily involved in the sensation of the skin around the ear, not the inner canal.

 

Option D. Facial nerve - While it contributes sensory fibers, it is not the primary cause of the cough reflex in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization
Do clerical work and check ECG

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of beta thalassemia undergoes a blood transfusion. During the transfusion, she develops anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion

 

Explanation

 

The development of anxiety, hypotension, and fever during a blood transfusion indicates a possible acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening reaction often due to ABO incompatibility. The immediate and most critical step in managing this reaction is to stop the transfusion immediately.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization: This may be considered in mild allergic reactions with symptoms like urticaria and itching, but not in the presence of hypotension and fever.

 

Option C. Do clerical work and check ECG: These are part of the subsequent steps, but the immediate action is to stop the transfusion.

 

Option D. Administer Hydrocortisone: This may be appropriate for mild allergic reactions but is not the first line of action in suspected severe transfusion reactions.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In any suspected severe transfusion reaction, immediately stop the transfusion to prevent further complications.

questions.text: What is the best test to diagnose Wilson’s disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatic copper estimation

 

Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other tissues, leading to hepato-lenticular degeneration. The most definitive and gold standard diagnostic test for Wilson’s disease is hepatic copper estimation, typically performed through a liver biopsy. This test directly measures the copper content in liver tissue, confirming the disease's diagnosis.

 

In addition, the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a copper deposit around the cornea, is a commonly seen ophthalmic feature of the disease. Another important ophthalmologic finding in Wilson's disease is the sunflower cataract, which occurs in the lens. These signs are crucial for diagnosing the hepato-lenticular degeneration associated with Wilson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine copper: This test measures the amount of copper excreted in the urine, which can be elevated in Wilson’s disease but is not definitive for diagnosis. It is often used to monitor treatment response rather than as a primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option B. Serum ceruloplasmin: Wilson’s disease is associated with low levels of ceruloplasmin, a copper-carrying protein. However, low ceruloplasmin levels alone are not specific to Wilson’s disease and can be seen in other conditions, making it a supportive but not definitive test.

 

Option C. Serum copper: Although serum copper levels may be low in Wilson’s disease due to decreased ceruloplasmin, free serum copper may be elevated. This test is not reliable for diagnosing Wilson’s disease and is better used as part of a comprehensive evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:


Hepatic copper estimation via liver biopsy is the gold standard test for diagnosing Wilson’s disease, providing a direct measure of copper accumulation in the liver.

questions.text: WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is related to: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Therapeutic abortion

 

The World Medical Association's (WMA) Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical considerations surrounding therapeutic abortion. This declaration emphasizes that medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) should be conducted under specific conditions to ensure it is ethical and safe.

 

The key focus areas of the Oslo Declaration include:

 

MTP must be done only due to:

 

  1. Health Reasons: Therapeutic abortion should only be performed when it is medically necessary for the health of the patient. This may include physical, mental, or social reasons that could adversely affect the well-being of the patient.
  2. Informed Consent: Both the patient and the healthcare provider must fully understand and agree to the procedure. It is essential that both parties are convinced of the necessity and appropriateness of the abortion.
  3. Legal Compliance: The procedure must comply with the local laws governing abortion in the specific region, territory, or country. Legal regulations vary, and it is crucial to adhere to them.
  4. Competent Personnel: The procedure should be carried out by competent surgeons. If the situation allows, trained professional health workers who are competent and authorized by law can also perform the procedure.

 

These principles ensure that therapeutic abortions are conducted in a manner that prioritizes the safety, rights, and well-being of the patient while adhering to ethical and legal standards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hunger: The Declaration of Oslo is not related to hunger. Hunger and food security issues are addressed by different international organizations and declarations, but not by this specific WMA declaration.

 

Option B. State of prisoners: The Oslo Declaration does not deal with the treatment or state of prisoners. Other international conventions, like the Geneva Conventions, cover the rights and treatment of prisoners.

 

Option C. Ethics in Medical Research: Although the WMA has issued other declarations related to ethics in medical research, such as the Declaration of Helsinki, Nuremberg code and Belmont report.

 

Additional Information

 

Declaration of Geneva: related to the physician's dedication to humanitarian goals of medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical guidelines surrounding therapeutic abortion, emphasizing health reasons, informed consent, legal compliance, and the requirement for competent medical personnel.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid. Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface. This in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B12 to be absorbed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: Incorrect as the primary site for folate absorption is the jejunum. While partial jejunal resection could impact folate absorption, the redundancy in folate absorption along the small intestine generally compensates unless the resection is extensive.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Incorrect because gastric ulcers are typically related to factors affecting the stomach lining, such as Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use, and are not directly caused by resections of the ileum or jejunum.

 

Option D. Constipation: Incorrect as constipation is more commonly associated with colonic function disruptions or changes in diet following gastrointestinal surgery, not specifically related to the ileum or jejunum resections which would more likely impact diarrhea due to reduced absorption capacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resection of the terminal ileum specifically compromises vitamin B12 absorption due to the loss of the primary site where the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is absorbed. This can lead to significant clinical issues related to vitamin B12 deficiency, such as anemia and neurological disturbances, unless managed with appropriate supplementation.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

 

  • Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with dysphagia for solid foods more than liquid for the last 3 months and has severe cachexia. What will be the best investigation to establish the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy with Biopsy

 

The patient's symptoms of dysphagia for solid foods more than liquids, coupled with severe cachexia, are highly suggestive of esophageal cancer.

 

Dysphagia for solids more than liquids typically indicates a structural problem in the esophagus. Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best initial investigation to directly visualize the esophagus and obtain tissue samples for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manometry: This is used to diagnose neuromuscular disorders of the esophagus, such as achalasia, but not typically used as the first-line investigation for suspected structural problems.

 

Option C. Barium swallow: This can provide imaging of the esophagus but is not as definitive as endoscopy with biopsy for diagnosing cancer.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): This is used for staging of cancer once the diagnosis is established but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with dysphagia predominantly for solids, especially with associated severe cachexia, upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis, often indicating esophageal cancer.

choices.text: Return to sleep is often delayed due to fear

questions.text: All of the following are features of Pavor nocturnus except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Return to sleep is often delayed due to fear

 

In sleep terrors (pavor nocturnus), the individual usually returns to sleep quickly after the episode ends. Despite the dramatic nature of these episodes including a piercing scream, intense fear, and autonomic arousal patients typically have amnesia for the event and do not remain awake or fearful afterward. This feature helps distinguish sleep terrors from nightmares, where the person often wakes up fully, remains fearful, and has difficulty falling back asleep.

 

 Other options:

 

  • Option A. Occurs during NREM sleep: Sleep terrors arise from slow-wave sleep (NREM stages 3 and 4), usually within the first third of the night, when this stage is most prominent.
  • Option B. Often associated with panicky scream: A piercing scream or loud cry often marks the onset of a sleep terror. This is typically followed by signs of extreme fear—e.g., tachycardia, sweating, and dilated pupils.
  • Option D. Does not recall event: Amnesia for the event is characteristic. Patients are typically unresponsive during the episode and later unable to recall what happened, unlike nightmares, which are often remembered in vivid detail.

 

Educational Objective:


Sleep terrors are NREM parasomnias that begin with a loud scream and intense autonomic arousal but are usually followed by quick return to sleep and no memory of the event. They differ from nightmares in their sleep stage origin, behavioral features, and recall after the episode.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with visual disturbances. An MRI reveals a lesion at the location marked in the image. Which of the following visual field defects is most likely associated with this lesion? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

The lesion refers to a craniopharyngioma, a tumor that arises from the remnants of Rathke's pouch, located near the pituitary gland.

 

Craniopharyngiomas are commonly found near the optic chiasm, where the crossing of the nasal fibers of the optic nerves occurs. When this tumor grows, it can compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia. This condition results in the loss of peripheral vision in both eyes because the tumor specifically damages the nasal fibers, which are responsible for peripheral vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single vision field loss: Single vision field loss would occur with damage to the optic nerve on one side, not at the optic chiasm. Craniopharyngiomas typically affect both nasal fibers at the chiasm, leading to a specific pattern of vision loss, not confined to a single visual field.

 

Option C. Complete blindness: Complete blindness would require extensive damage to the entire visual pathway, which is not typical of craniopharyngioma unless the tumor has become exceptionally large and invasive. The usual presentation is partial vision loss, particularly affecting the peripheral fields.

 

Option D. Homonymous hemianopia: Homonymous hemianopia occurs when there is damage to the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or occipital cortex on one side, leading to loss of the same visual field in both eyes. This pattern does not fit with craniopharyngioma, which specifically affects the optic chiasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngiomas commonly cause bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm, resulting in peripheral vision loss on both sides.

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

 

The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is crucial for breathing. The mnemonic "3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive" helps to remember that the phrenic nerve arises from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5. This nerve travels downward, passing in front of the lung root, to reach the diaphragm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: The midbrain is not involved in the origin of the phrenic nerve. The midbrain primarily deals with functions such as vision, hearing, motor control, sleep/wake, arousal, and temperature regulation.

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is involved in various functions including breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance. However, it does not give rise to the phrenic nerve.

 

Option C. Medulla: The medulla oblongata regulates vital functions such as heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure. While it contains nuclei for several cranial nerves, it is not the origin of the phrenic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

questions.text: The ideal number of ANC visits is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12-15

 

Antenatal care (ANC) visits are crucial for monitoring the health of both the mother and the fetus during pregnancy. Different guidelines recommend varying numbers of visits:

 

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India): Recommends at least 4 visits.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Suggests 8 visits, referring to them as "contacts."
  • American guidelines and practical recommendations: Advise 12-15 visits, ensuring comprehensive care.

 

The ideal number of ANC visits, according to American guidelines and actual practice, is 12-15. This schedule is designed to closely monitor the pregnancy and promptly address any complications:

 

  • Monthly visits until 28 weeks of gestation.
  • Bi-weekly visits from 28 to 36 weeks.
  • Weekly visits from 36 weeks until delivery.

 

This frequency allows for timely detection and management of potential issues, ensuring the best outcomes for both mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of ANC visits is 12-15, as recommended by American guidelines, to ensure comprehensive prenatal care.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a criteria for making a diagnosis of an anaphylactic reaction?  (INICET MAY 2024)

  1. Swollen lips and urticaria
  2. Hypertension
  3. Breathing difficulty
  4. Persistent abdominal pain and vomiting
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Anaphylactic reaction is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that is classified as a type I hypersensitivity reaction. This reaction involves the rapid release of histamine and other mediators from mast cells and basophils, leading to a variety of symptoms.

 

Key Criteria for Anaphylactic Reaction:

 

1. Swollen lips and urticaria: These are common manifestations of anaphylaxis due to histamine release causing increased vascular permeability and vasodilation, leading to swelling and hives.

 

3. Breathing difficulty: The release of leukotrienes and other mediators can cause bronchospasm, leading to respiratory distress and difficulty in breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Hypertension

 

Anaphylactic reactions typically cause hypotension (low blood pressure) due to widespread vasodilation and increased capillary permeability, not hypertension.

 

4. Persistent abdominal pain and vomiting

 

While abdominal pain and vomiting can occur in anaphylaxis, they are not the most typical or defining features. Persistent symptoms are less commonly associated with anaphylaxis compared to the more acute and severe symptoms like swelling and breathing difficulty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of swollen lips and urticaria along with breathing difficulty are key criteria for diagnosing an anaphylactic reaction, while hypertension and persistent abdominal pain are not typical features.

questions.text: In management of cervical cancer, which therapy is given along with radiotherapy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Platinum based chemotherapy

 

In cervical cancer management, cisplatin-based chemotherapy (platinum-based) is given along with radiotherapy. Cisplatin acts as a radiosensitizer, which means it increases the sensitivity of the tissue to radiotherapy, making the treatment more effective. The combination of cisplatin followed by radiotherapy is a standard treatment protocol in cervical cancer management.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Immunotherapy: While immunotherapy has shown promise in some cancers, it is not the standard first-line treatment given along with radiotherapy in cervical cancer management.

 

Option C. Hormone therapy: Cervical cancer is not hormone-dependent, unlike some breast and endometrial cancers. Therefore, hormone therapy is not effective in its treatment.

 

Option D. Targeted therapy: Though targeted therapies are being studied, they are not the standard treatment given along with radiotherapy in cervical cancer management.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remember that platinum-based chemotherapy (cisplatin) is used as a radiosensitizer along with radiotherapy in the management of cervical cancer.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

 

This statement is incorrect because it is the female mite, not the male, that burrows into the skin. The male mites mainly stay on the surface of the skin and do not create burrows like the females do.

 

The clinical background is probably suggestive Scabies. The given image depicts Itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow.

 

A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day, and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow.

 

The life cycle has 4 stages: Egg, Larva, Nymph, and Adult. The adult mites live for 1 to 2 months. 

 

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasite in the epidermis.

 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Life history has 4 stages: The lifecycle of Sarcoptes scabiei consists of the egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages, correctly described in the statement.

 

Option B. Larvae have 3 pairs of legs: The larvae of the scabies mite indeed have three pairs of legs, distinguishing them from the adult mites.

 

Option C. The entire life cycle takes about 15 days: The lifecycle from egg to mature mite, under ideal conditions, typically spans around 15 days, making this statement accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite is responsible for burrowing into the skin and laying eggs, which leads to the intense itching and characteristic rash seen in scabies. Recognizing the specific behavior of the female mite in the transmission and lifecycle of scabies is crucial for effective diagnosis and management of the condition.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the ECG shown below?(INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mobitz type 2 block


The ECG shows bradycardia with regular, constant PR intervals in the conducted beats and intermittently dropped QRS complexes, which are indicative of Mobitz type 2 block. This type of atrioventricular block is characterized by:

 

  • Constant PR interval in the conducted beats
  • Intermittent non-conducted P waves (dropped QRS complexes)

 

This distinguishes Mobitz type 2 block from other types of heart block:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>200 ms) but all P waves are followed by QRS complexes. This is not observed in the given ECG.

 

Option B. Third degree heart block: Complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with no relationship between them. The given ECG does not show this pattern.

 

Option C. Wenckebach heart block (Mobitz type 1): Progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a QRS complex is dropped. The given ECG shows constant PR intervals, not progressively increasing.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mobitz type 2 block is identified by a constant PR interval with intermittently non-conducted P waves. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for appropriate management, as Mobitz type 2 can progress to complete heart block and often requires a pacemaker.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: Anterior fontanelle closes at which age? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12-24 months

 

The anterior fontanelle is the largest of the fontanelles in an infant's skull, located at the junction of the frontal and parietal bones. It is diamond-shaped and is clinically significant as it remains open for a period after birth, allowing for the growth of the baby's brain and skull. The closure of the anterior fontanelle typically occurs between 12 to 24 months of age. This is an important developmental milestone and can vary slightly depending on individual growth patterns.

 

 

 

The provided images and discussion indicate that the anterior fontanelle is the last to close among the fontanelles. The posterior fontanelle closes around 3 months, the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle around 6 months, and the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelle around 12 months. Therefore, the anterior fontanelle, which closes between 12 to 24 months, is correctly identified by option A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 0-3 months: Incorrect. The posterior fontanelle typically closes during this period.

 

Option C. 10-12 months: Incorrect. The fontanelles closing around this age are the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelles.

 

Option D. 3-6 months: Incorrect. It corresponds to the closure time of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle, not the anterior fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 12 to 24 months of age, making this a key point for assessing normal infant development.

questions.text: The Alvarado score is used for the diagnosis of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Acute Appendicitis

 

Explanation:

 

The Alvarado score (also known as the MANTRELS score) is a clinical scoring system specifically developed to diagnose acute appendicitis. It uses 8 criteria with a total possible score of 10 points. The components of the score include: Migratory RIF pain (1 point), Anorexia (1 point), Nausea/vomiting (1 point), Tenderness in RIF (2 points), Rebound tenderness (1 point), Elevated temperature (1 point), Leukocytosis (2 points), and Shift to left of neutrophils (1 point). A score of 7 or more is strongly predictive of acute appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatitis - Pancreatitis diagnosis relies on clinical features, elevated serum amylase/lipase levels, and imaging. The Ranson criteria or APACHE II scores are used for severity assessment, not the Alvarado score.

 

Option B. Cholecystitis - Diagnosis relies on Murphy's sign, ultrasonography findings, and laboratory values. The Tokyo Guidelines provide diagnostic criteria for acute cholecystitis, not the Alvarado score.

 

Option C. Turner's Syndrome - This is a genetic condition diagnosed by karyotype analysis showing 45, XO. Clinical scoring systems are not used for the diagnosis of genetic conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Alvarado score is a validated clinical decision tool specifically designed for diagnosing acute appendicitis, with a score ≥7 having high diagnostic value, helping to reduce negative appendectomy rates.

questions.text: Which gas is primarily used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lungs? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C) CO

 

Explanation:

 

Carbon monoxide (CO) is the primary gas used to measure the diffusing capacity of the lungs, known as DLCO (Diffusion capacity of Lung for CO). CO is ideal for this measurement because it has approximately 210 times greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen. This extremely high affinity ensures that the rate-limiting step in CO uptake is the diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, not blood flow or binding to hemoglobin, making it an excellent gas for assessing membrane diffusion properties.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. O2 - Oxygen is not used for measuring diffusing capacity because its uptake is affected by both diffusion and perfusion. Additionally, as oxygen binds to hemoglobin, the pressure gradient decreases, making measurements less reliable.
  • Option B. CO2 - Carbon dioxide's transfer is much faster than oxygen (20 times more diffusible) and is primarily limited by ventilation and blood flow rather than membrane properties, making it unsuitable for diffusion capacity measurements.
  • Option D. N2O - Nitrous oxide is used in some pulmonary function tests but is not used for measuring diffusing capacity. It is primarily used in ventilation/perfusion assessments rather than membrane diffusion properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DLCO test uses carbon monoxide because its extremely high affinity for hemoglobin creates a steep concentration gradient that remains constant during the test, making the diffusion process across the alveolar-capillary membrane the primary limitation to gas transfer.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with weakness and fatigue. Lab reports showed low Hb and high reticulocyte count. WBC and platelet counts were normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemolytic anemia

 

The presence of a high reticulocyte count in the context of anemia indicates that the bone marrow is responding appropriately by producing more red blood cells to compensate for the anemia. This is a typical finding in hemolytic anemia, where there is increased destruction of red blood cells in the periphery, leading to an increase in reticulocyte production as the bone marrow attempts to replace the lost cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is typically characterized by a low reticulocyte count due to impaired erythropoiesis in response to chronic inflammation or disease.

 

Option B. Aplastic crisis: In aplastic crisis, there is a failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells, leading to low reticulocyte counts, along with low white blood cell and platelet counts.

 

Option D. Pernicious anemia: This is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to impaired DNA synthesis and resulting in megaloblastic anemia. It typically presents with low reticulocyte counts and can also affect white blood cells and platelets, causing pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of anemia with a high reticulocyte count and normal white blood cell and platelet counts, hemolytic anemia is the likely diagnosis, indicating increased peripheral destruction of red blood cells and a compensatory increase in reticulocyte production by the bone marrow.

questions.text: At what pressure is the pop-up valve released in bag and mask ventilation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-40 cm of H2O

     

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation is a safety feature designed to release pressure when it exceeds a certain limit to prevent barotrauma to the patient. This valve typically releases at a pressure range of 30-40 cm of water (H2O). This pressure setting helps ensure that the air is delivered to the patient safely without causing excessive force that could damage the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation releases at a pressure of 30-40 cm of H2O to prevent excessive pressure that could harm the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following represent Median Nerve Entrapment Syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. All of the above

 

All three syndromes - Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, Pronator Syndrome, and Kiloh-Nevin Syndrome - involve entrapment of the median nerve at different anatomical locations. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is the most common entrapment syndrome, occurring at the wrist where the median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel. Pronator Syndrome involves compression of the median nerve at the proximal forearm beneath various structures including the ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origin of pronator teres or FDS. Kiloh-Nevin Syndrome specifically affects the Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN), which is a motor branch of the median nerve.

 

Other Options: 

 

None of the individual options (A, B, or C) alone would be incorrect in this case since each syndrome represents a type of median nerve entrapment. The question asks which "represent Median Nerve Entrapment Syndrome" and all three conditions qualify.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Median nerve entrapment can occur at multiple anatomical locations resulting in distinct clinical syndromes: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (most common, at wrist), Pronator Syndrome (proximal forearm), and Kiloh-Nevin Syndrome (affecting the Anterior Interosseous branch).

questions.text: A patient's relatives sent a message on social media to the consulting doctor, unaware about the other investigations. But he mentioned that urinary coproporphyrin is positive. What is the probable cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

 

Lead poisoning is known to interfere with the heme synthesis pathway by inhibiting key enzymes such as delta-aminolevulinic acid dehydratase, coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and ferrochelatase. The inhibition of coproporphyrinogen oxidase leads to an accumulation of coproporphyrin in the urine, which is a hallmark of lead poisoning. This accumulation makes urinary coproporphyrin a valuable diagnostic marker for lead toxicity, as indicated in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers. It primarily affects the respiratory system and does not cause an increase in urinary coproporphyrin levels.

 

Option C. Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, affecting lung tissue. It does not influence heme synthesis or cause elevated urinary coproporphyrin levels.

 

Option D. Mercury poisoning: Mercury poisoning affects the nervous and renal systems but does not specifically impact the enzymes involved in heme synthesis. It does not lead to increased levels of urinary coproporphyrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning inhibits enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, resulting in elevated urinary coproporphyrin levels, which is a key diagnostic indicator.

questions.text: Reiter's syndrome is associated with: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

Explanation

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen. This association is part of a broader category of diseases called seronegative spondyloarthropathies. The key conditions linked with HLA-B27 include:

 

  • Ankylosing Spondylitis: This condition has the highest association with HLA-B27.
  • Psoriatic Arthritis: A form of arthritis that affects some people with psoriasis.
  • Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's Syndrome): Characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.
  • Enteropathic Arthritis: Associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. HLA B51: It is linked with Behçet's disease.

 

Option C. HLA DR4: Associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. HLA B8: Associated with diseases such as myasthenia gravis and celiac disease.

 

Educational Objectives:


Reiter's syndrome is part of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the regulation of enzyme activity through phosphorylation or dephosphorylation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Covalent modification

 

Phosphorylation and dephosphorylation involve the covalent addition or removal of phosphate groups to/from enzymes. This is a type of covalent modification because:

 

  • Phosphate groups are attached through covalent bonds to specific amino acid residues (usually serine, threonine, or tyrosine)
  • The changes are reversible but require specific enzymes (kinases and phosphatases)
  • This process is regulated by hormones like glucagon (increases phosphorylation via cAMP) and insulin (promotes dephosphorylation)

 

Common examples include:

 

  • Glycogen metabolism enzymes: 
    • Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by phosphorylation
    • Glycogen synthase is inhibited by phosphorylation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive inhibition: Incorrect because

 

  • This involves reversible binding of inhibitor at active site
  • No covalent modification occurs
  • Competes with substrate for binding

 

Option B. Repression: Incorrect because

 

  • This regulates enzyme synthesis at gene level
  • Does not involve modification of existing enzyme
  • Acts by controlling transcription

 

Option C. Allosteric inhibition: Incorrect because

 

  • Involves non-covalent binding at regulatory site
  • Causes conformational changes
  • No chemical modification of enzyme structure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphorylation/dephosphorylation represents a covalent modification mechanism for regulating enzyme activity through the addition or removal of phosphate groups.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

 

The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

 

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

  • A tiny stainless-steel implant called Ex-PRESS is used to treat glaucoma.
  • It is implanted during a modified trabeculectomy underneath a scleral flap.
  • Hypotony-related complications are less common than with conventional trabeculectomy.
  • By creating a communication between the anterior chamber and the sub-space/sub-conjunctival Tennon's space, glaucoma drainage devices enable aqueous outflow.
  • While formerly only used in high-risk patients or after a failed trabulectomy, these devices are gaining popularity.
  • The commonly used devices are as follows:
    • ﻿﻿Shunts using episcleral explants
    • ﻿﻿Ahmed glaucoma valve- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
    • ﻿﻿Baerveldt implant- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Mini-shunts
    • ﻿﻿Ex-Press™M Mini-Shunt- Stainless steel
    • ﻿﻿iStent®- Titanium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ahmed Glaucoma Valve:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Contains a valve mechanism to prevent hypotony.
  • Popular for its ease of implantation and reliable outcomes.
  • Used in cases requiring controlled aqueous humor outflow but differs in design and function from the Ex-Press™ implant

 

Option C. Molteno Implant:

  • Made of polypropylene plate and silicone plate.
  • One of the earliest glaucoma drainage devices, offering various plate sizes.

 

Option D. Baerveldt Implant:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Designed to provide large surface area for filtration.
  • Requires ligation to prevent early postoperative hypotony.
  • Also used for glaucoma management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant is a minimally invasive device used during modified trabeculectomy to enhance aqueous drainage and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. This implant is characterized by its stainless-steel construction and effectiveness in controlling glaucoma with fewer hypotony-related complications.

questions.text: Which of the following bariatric procedures has been shown to offer maximum weight reduction? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS)

 

Explanation:

 

BPD/DS produces the greatest weight loss among all bariatric procedures. It achieves maximum weight loss (70-80% excess weight loss at 3 years) compared to other procedures. This is primarily due to its powerful malabsorptive mechanism combined with the restrictive component of sleeve gastrectomy. The procedure creates a significant reduction in the absorptive surface of the intestine through the creation of a common channel of 75-125 cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding - Gastric banding produces the least weight loss among the standard procedures, with only 40-50% Excess weight loss (EWL) at 3 years. It functions purely as a restrictive procedure without malabsorption, depending on reduced food intake rather than reduced absorption.

 

Option C. Roux-en-Y Gastric bypass - While effective, gastric bypass produces 50-60% Excess weight loss (EWL) at 3 years. This is substantially less than BPD/DS, though it has fewer nutritional complications and is more commonly performed.

 

Option D. Sleeve gastrectomy - Similar to gastric bypass, sleeve gastrectomy produces 50-60% EWL at 3 years. It works primarily through restriction and hormonal changes rather than malabsorption.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While BPD/DS produces the maximum weight loss (70-80% EWL), it also carries the highest risk of malnutrition and requires lifelong monitoring and supplementation. The choice of bariatric procedure should balance weight loss goals with nutritional risks and patient compliance factors.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

In patients with AIDS, regardless of their CD4 count, the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae. This organism is a leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients.

 

The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, bronchial breath sounds, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray is consistent with bacterial pneumonia. While Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii) is a common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts, it typically presents with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and less commonly with lobar consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³. It usually presents with diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, especially post-viral or in hospital-acquired cases, but it is not the most common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients. It can also present with abscess formation and necrotizing pneumonia, which were not described here.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in younger patients, but it is less likely in this immunocompromised patient with typical lobar consolidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 years

 

  • The X-ray shows 7 Carpal bones. Thus, minimum age is 5 here.
  • Also, pisiform is not seen. Hence, the age is between 5-12.
  • The best answer is 7 years as the normal age range for appearance of pisiform is 8-12 years.

 

BONE AGE

 

  • Left hand and wrist X-ray PA view – most commonly used for bone age assessment – Based on appearance of carpal bones
  • First to appear is Capitate, then in a counter-clockwise fashion except pisiform which is the last carpal bone to appear
  • Pisiform is ossified at the age of nine to 13 years as evident from different studies.
  • The appearance of ossification center of pisiform bone is one of the important evidence for estimating age among young children between nine to 13 years.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are approved in all of the following except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rett Syndrome

 

Rett Syndrome: A rare genetic neurological disorder that primarily affects girls and leads to severe cognitive and physical impairments. While new treatments are being explored, cannabinoids are not currently approved for managing this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD) formulations such as Epidiolex, have been FDA-approved for use in treating certain epileptic syndromes. These include:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: A severe form of epilepsy that begins in infancy, characterized by prolonged seizures.

 

Option B. Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome: A childhood-onset epilepsy that involves multiple types of seizures and often results in cognitive impairment.

 

Option C. Tuberous Sclerosis: A genetic disorder that causes benign tumors to form in many parts of the body, including the brain, which can lead to seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannabinoids, such as Epidiolex, are approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, and Tuberous Sclerosis, but not for Rett Syndrome.

 

Note - High-dose Epidiolex is an FDA-approved oil formulation of CBD for use as an add-on treatment for Dravet's and Lennox-Gastaut syndromes and tuberous sclerosis epilepsies. There is clinical evidence for CBD, at lower doses, as an anxiolytic for the treatment of posttraumatic stress, anxiety, and relapse of substance use disorders. Animal studies suggest that this effect of CBD may be mediated by the 5-hydroxytryptamine 1A receptor.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chiari malformation

 

Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the presence of tonsillar herniation below the foramen magnum. In the given image, the cerebellar tonsils are seen herniating more than 5 mm below the line drawn between the basion (the lower part of the clivus) and the opisthion (the lower part of the occiput), which is characteristic of Chiari I malformation. This displacement of the tonsils is known as tonsillar ectopia, a hallmark feature of Chiari malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition is characterized by an enlarged posterior fossa, a posterior fossa cyst, and agenesis of the cerebellar vermis, none of which are seen in the provided image. Therefore, Dandy Walker malformation is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Vein of Galen malformation: This malformation presents as a large midline vascular structure, typically a signal void due to the dilated vein, which is absent in the provided image. The lack of these vascular changes rules out Vein of Galen malformation.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Encephaloceles are characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull. There is no evidence of brain tissue protruding from the skull in the image, ruling out encephalocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chiari malformation is diagnosed by the inferior displacement of the cerebellar tonsils below the foramen magnum, typically more than 5 mm, seen on imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to impair scholastic performance? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. PICA

 

Explanation: 

 

PICA is an eating disorder characterized by the persistent consumption of non-nutritive, non-food substances (such as dirt, clay, paper, paint chips, etc.) that is inappropriate for the developmental level of the individual. While PICA can have health consequences due to ingestion of potentially harmful substances, it does not directly impact cognitive functions or learning abilities in the way the other listed conditions do. Therefore, PICA is least likely to directly impair scholastic performance.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (Incorrect): ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. These symptoms directly interfere with learning processes, classroom behavior, and academic achievement. Children with ADHD often struggle with focusing during lessons, completing assignments, following instructions, and staying organized, all of which significantly impact scholastic performance.
  • Option B. Specific Learning Disability (SLD) (Incorrect): SLD is defined by significant impairment in one or more specific academic skills (reading, writing, mathematics) despite normal intellectual functioning. By definition, SLD directly impacts scholastic performance, as it specifically affects the acquisition and use of academic skills.
  • Option C. Anxiety (Incorrect): Anxiety disorders can significantly impair scholastic performance through several mechanisms. Test anxiety can lead to underperformance in examinations, social anxiety can interfere with class participation and group activities, and generalized anxiety can affect concentration, working memory, and overall cognitive functioning in the classroom setting.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When considering psychiatric disorders that impact academic performance, it's important to differentiate between conditions that directly affect cognitive functions, learning processes, or classroom behavior (like ADHD, learning disabilities, and anxiety) versus conditions that primarily affect other domains of functioning (like certain eating disorders). PICA, as an eating disorder characterized by consumption of non-food substances, has physiological and health implications but does not directly impact the cognitive processes essential for learning.

questions.text: A patient had a drop in Systolic Blood Pressure of 15 mm Hg during inspiration. Which of the following is NOT associated with it? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation

 

A drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration is termed pulsus paradoxus. This phenomenon is seen in several conditions, including cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax.
