Cardiac tamponade is a classic cause of pulsus paradoxus due to the restriction of ventricular filling during inspiration. Status asthmaticus and tension pneumothorax also cause significant intrathoracic pressure changes, leading to a similar hemodynamic effect.

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, on the other hand, is not associated with pulsus paradoxus. Instead, HCM can be associated with pulsus bisferiens, a double-peaked pulse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac Tamponade: This is a well-known cause of pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option B. Status Asthmaticus: This can cause pulsus paradoxus due to severe obstruction and changes in intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Tension Pneumothorax: This condition can also lead to pulsus paradoxus due to significant intrathoracic pressure changes.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulsus paradoxus, a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, is seen in conditions like cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax. It is not associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can present with pulsus bisferiens instead.

questions.text: The typical lifespan for a Japanese woman is 87 years. Due to recent progress in cervical cancer testing, her life expectancy has risen by 15 years. With a healthcare utility value of 0.8, what can be determined based on these provided parameters? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) QALY

 

Quality Adjusted Life Years (QALYs)

 

  • QALY is a measure of both quality and quantity of life lived
  • QALY is years of life lived in perfect health
  • QALY is used in assessing the value of money of a medical intervention
  • QALY calculation is simple: the change in utility value induced by the treatment is multiplied by the duration of the treatment effect to provide the number of QALYs gained

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HALE: Health-adjusted life expectancy - equivalent number of years in “full health” that a new-born can expect to live based on current rates of ill health and mortality

 

Option B. DALY: Is disability-adjusted life years, which is the best measure of disease burden, including both reduction in life expectancy and diminished quality of life. It can measure both mortality and disability together.

 

DALY = YLL (years of life lost) + YLD (years lost to disability)

 

Option C.  Sullivan’s Index, now called DFLE (Disability-free life expectancy): Means the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability (given the current mortality and disability). It is calculated as Life expectancy minus duration of disability

 

Educational Objective:

 

QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years) is the measure used to assess the value of medical interventions by considering both the quality and quantity of life lived. In this scenario, the increase in life expectancy due to cervical cancer testing and the given utility value are used to calculate QALYs gained.

choices.text: ACL, MCL, and Medial Meniscus tear
ACL, MCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear
ACL, PCL, and Medial Meniscus tear
ACL, PCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear

questions.text: The most common triad of acute knee injuries seen in athletes includes a combination of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ACL, MCL, and Medial Meniscus tear

 

  • The combination of ACL, MCL, and Medial Meniscus tear is known as O'Donoghue triad, which is considered a dangerous injury pattern 
  • The triad is represented by the acronym "MAM" - Medial collateral ligament, Anterior cruciate ligament, and Medial meniscus. 
  • This injury typically occurs when valgus force and rotational stress are applied to the knee joint during athletic activities.
  • This combination typically results from a valgus stress with external rotation of the tibia on a planted foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL, MCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear: This combination doesn't represent the classic O'Donoghue triad. While ACL and MCL injuries can occur together, the medial meniscus is the third component in the classic triad, not the lateral meniscus.

 

Option C. ACL, PCL, and Medial Meniscus tear: This combination involves both cruciate ligaments, which follows a different injury mechanism. PCL injuries typically occur with posterior force on the tibia, rather than the valgus/rotational force that produces O'Donoghue triad.

 

Option D. ACL, PCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear: This combination includes both cruciate ligaments with the lateral meniscus, which would require a complex injury mechanism not typical of most athletic injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

O'Donoghue triad consists of injury to the Medial collateral ligament (M), Anterior cruciate ligament (A), and Medial meniscus (M), creating the "MAM" pattern that typically results from valgus force combined with rotation.

questions.text: Identify the following sign: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tear drop sign

 

Explanation: 


The image shows the tear drop sign (also called hanging drop sign) because:

 

  • Shows herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus
  • Appears as a tear-shaped shadow on imaging
  • Characteristic finding in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • Occurs due to disruption of orbital floor allowing downward displacement of orbital contents
  • Important radiological sign in trauma cases

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Steeple sign

 

  • Seen in croup
  • Shows subglottic narrowing on AP view
  • Appears as narrowing of upper airway
  • Different radiological appearance

 

 

Option C. Thumb sign

 

  • Seen in acute epiglottitis
  • Shows swollen epiglottis on lateral neck X-ray
  • Appears as thumb-like shadow
  • Different anatomical location

 

 

Option D. Sail sign

 

  • Not a commonly used radiological sign in ENT
  • Different appearance and location
  • Not related to orbital or sinus pathology

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recognize the tear drop sign (hanging drop sign) as characteristic radiological finding in orbital floor fractures showing herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus
